abstract.p: Eve MacSweeney interviews Max Wigram, co-curator of London's Royal Academy of Arts new 'Apocalypse' show; photos (M) (special section, Men's Fashions of The Times) (part 2 of 2-part section)

block.p: It's that time again. London's Royal Academy of Arts, which generated the much-ballyhooed ''Sensation'' exhibition in Brooklyn last year, has now unveiled the equally throat-grabbing ''Apocalypse,'' a show cheerily subtitled ''Beauty and Horror in Contemporary Art.''

Instrumental in picking the 13 international artists whose worldview fit this description was Max Wigram, chosen by the academy's Norman Rosenthal to be his co-curator. An artist, art history graduate and former Bruce Weber model who ran a noncommercial artists' space in the mid-90's, Wigram, 34, is used to navigating the choppy waters of shock and pop culture that flow through the current landscape of contemporary art. ''Artists use shock as a material now,'' he says. ''It's a dangerous game to play because if you can't back it up with content, it's just gratuitous. Good art has to stand up to every form of criticism.''

It's that time again. London's Royal Academy of Arts, which generated the much-ballyhooed ''Sensation'' exhibition in Brooklyn last year, has now unveiled the equally throat-grabbing ''Apocalypse,'' a show cheerily subtitled ''Beauty and Horror in Contemporary Art.''

Instrumental in picking the 13 international artists whose worldview fit this description was Max Wigram, chosen by the academy's Norman Rosenthal to be his co-curator. An artist, art history graduate and former Bruce Weber model who ran a noncommercial artists' space in the mid-90's, Wigram, 34, is used to navigating the choppy waters of shock and pop culture that flow through the current landscape of contemporary art. ''Artists use shock as a material now,'' he says. ''It's a dangerous game to play because if you can't back it up with content, it's just gratuitous. Good art has to stand up to every form of criticism.''

Wigram sought out fresh pastures of apprehension in the work of Gregor Schneider, a German artist who builds gruesomely suggestive rooms within rooms, and a debut artwork about sex and domestic violence by Chris Cunningham, the video director known for his work with Madonna, Bjork and Aphex Twin. ''Apocalypse'' is not without its ambiguous charms -- witness the Turner Prize contender Wolfgang Tillmans's brooding sunsets, below right -- but the show is clearly not for the faint-hearted.

Is he concerned about the response? ''It depends on how I wake up in the morning,'' Wigram says. ''Sometimes I think, Oh my God, what on earth's going to go off this time? But this work is so good. And if I really wanted to shock people, I could do it, let me tell you.''
Eve MacSweeney is a writer and editor based in New York.
